title-group.article-title: Dominantly Inherited Nonprogressive Cerebellar Hypoplasia Identified In Utero
title-group.subtitle: No Doubt

body.p: We thank Dr Poretti and Dr Bolthauser for giving us the opportunity to clarify the prenatal imaging features that lead to a definite diagnosis of autosomal dominant cerebellar hypoplasia.

Because it is clear that the mother does not have rhombencephalosynapsis, it is difficult to understand how the distinguished authors could perceive that the fetus had an entirely different disorder affecting the same organ.

The diagnosis of cerebellar hypoplasia was performed based on repeated ultrasonographic examinations supplemented by magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) at 25 weeks of gestation. Multiple images at orthogonal planes were obtained by both techniques, which demonstrated the existence of the vermis separating two clearly differentiated cerebellar hemispheres without folial continuity across the midline; both the vermis and the cerebellar hemispheres were hypoplastic. To relieve the authors’ doubts, we provide additional prenatal ultrasound images of our patient (Figure 1A-C) as well as an image of a fetus with rhombencephalosynapsis for comparison (Figure 1D).

caption.p: (A-C) Ultrasonographic axial, sagittal, and coronal images of our patient at 28 wk 6 d of gestation. Showing the cerebellar hemispheres (CH) and the vermis as an echogenic structure (between arrows). Note the vermian hypoplasia in B. (D) Coronal view for comparison of a 30-wk 0-d fetus with rhombencephalosynapsis. The vermis is not depicted; note the folial continuity (between arrows).

body.p:
Since the publication of our paper, we have obtained a postnatal MRI, performed at 8 months of age, that confirms the prenatal diagnosis. The MRI clearly demonstrates a hypoplastic cerebellum with less prominent involvement of the vermis and a hypoplastic pons (Figure 2A and B). The child shows ataxia and developmental delay similar to her mother's development according to the grandmother.
Figure 2.
(A) Coronal T2-weighted image at 8 mo of age demonstrates hypoplastic cerebellar hemispheres with a clear vermis separating the hemispheres. (B) Midsagittal T1-weighted image at 8 months of age demonstrates hypoplastic vermis and pons.
We agree that at present we have not found the involved gene but it is obvious that this form of cerebellar hypoplasia is dominantly inherited and not acquired.

As we discussed in the article, our family is indeed unique with a more pronounced cerebellar hypoplasia compared to the other described families with autosomal dominant nonprogressive cerebellar ataxia. We hope our reply and the additional images will convince the authors that our family represents a new type of autosomal dominant nonprogressive cerebellar hypoplasia.
